results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 10 shows more of the special race-meeting held at Flemington Racecourse, the tennis at Kooyong, and a service held at St. Paul’s Cathedral.

Detailed Description Reel 10:

Opens with Title “Duke of Edinburgh Australian Cup” followed by race footage of the last stretch and race finish. 00:00:25:00 Title “Queen Elizabeth Stakes”, followed by footage of horses and jockeys in the mounting yard. 00:00:50:00 footage of entire race to 00:01:12:00 then horses - with jockeys still mounted - exit to mounting yards. 00:01:40:00 to 00:03:23:00 the Queen presents winners’ trophies. 00:03:44:00 Title “Tennis at Kooyong”, followed by shot of Kooyong Stadium (Kooyong Tennis Centre) scoreboard displaying “International Match Australia v Sth. Africa”, footage of game and crowd scenes. 00:04:05:00 - 00:05:34:00 Queen and Duke arrive separately and move to seats amongst crowd. 00:05:45:00 - 00:06:35:00 Queen presents trophies in middle of court. 00:06:36:00 Title “Divine Service Cathedral Church of St. Paul Sunday, 28th. February, 1954”, followed by shots of St Paul’s Cathedral and crowds outside. 00:07:01:0 a good shot of Flinders Street Station and the station verandas along Swanston St. 00:07:27:00 Queen and Duke arrive and enter Cathedral. 00:08:01:00 couple leave and re-enter car, driving off through waving crowds. Dignitaries and churchmen on steps of Cathedral, at 00:08:41:00 Robert Menzies (then Prime Minister of Australia) is seen leaving, acknowledging crowd and getting into car.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 9 we see the Royal tour in the Victorian regional town of Hamilton, then attending a special race meeting at Flemington Racecourse.

Detailed Description Reel 9:

Starts with Title “Visit to Hamilton: Departure from Melbourne Airport (Overseas Terminal) Friday, February, 26th. 1954.” Tarmac and crowd scenes at Essendon (Melbourne) Airport. 00:01:06:00 Queen and Duke board plane. 00:01:36:00 plane taking off. 00:01:55:00 various officials boarding another plane. 00:02:53:00 plane landing. 00:03:02:00 arrival at Hamilton, Queen and Duke exit plane, followed by crowd scenes and presentation on dais. 00:03:43:00 motorcade through Hamilton (local streets and buildings) followed by greetings and crowd scenes at an official reception (at what appears to be a local sports ground). 00:04:56:00 Title “Flemington Race Meeting Saturday, February, 27th. 1954.” followed by shot of betting windows at Flemington, crowd scenes, people placing bets, close-ups of fashions and millinery styles. 00:05:35:00 Queen and Duke in open car, with mounted police. 00:05:59:00 greetings from VRC officials 00:07:15:00 mounting yard. 00:07:26:00 Title “Newmarket Handicap”, followed by interspersed scenes of crowd and horse-race. 00:08:01:00 Queen leaves stand and crowds begin to disperse.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 8 captures the Queen opening the Victorian State Parliament, and the Queen and Duke meeting with Australian armed forces veterans at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG).

Detailed Description Reel 8:

Opens with Title “Opening of Parliament: Thursday, 25th. February, 1954.” followed by shots of Government House and gardens. 00:00:35:00 Queen (in state dress) and Duke exit and get into open car, which leaves Government House and moves along St. Kilda Road and city streets with crowd shots on the way. 00:02:06:00 inside State Parliament. 00:02:19:00 leaving State Parliament through crowds and back into car. 00:03:19:00 Title “Assembly of Ex-Servicemen’s and Women’s Organisations, Junior Legatees and War Widows. Melbourne Cricket Ground.” 00:03:30:00 marching military bands, veterans in wheelchairs, and arrival of Queen and Duke in open car, which drives around perimeter then to centre of ground. 00:05:06:00 Philip makes speech from dais. 00:05:20:00 children present flowers. 00:05:58:00 footage of various groups marching. 00:07:00:00 Queen and Duke leave dais and speak with veterans. 00:07:58 to end - Queen and Duke re-enter open car and leave Melbourne Cricket Ground.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was our first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

Reel 7 shows us more of the crowds and celebrations in central Melbourne.

Detailed Description Reel 7:

Opens with crowd scenes and aerial shots of motorcade along Spring Street end of Bourke Street, then arrival of motorcade at Victorian State Parliament. 00:00:38:00 marching band playing along street in front of crowds in roadside bleachers. 00:00:53:00 out-of-focus street parade scenes. 00:01:09:00 Queens Guard marching band. 00:01:19:00 mounted police. 00:01:54:00 Queens Guard marches up Swanston Street from Princes Bridge (and a press photographer gets caught by camera and hurries out of shot). 00:02:17:00 - 00:02:44:00 footage of the massive crowd in Swanston Street. Various crowd scenes in Melbourne CBD and at Government House. Ends with shots of motorcade on Swanston Street with Melbourne Town Hall in the background, and police holding back the crowd on the street.

results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was our first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This collection of silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 6 we see some marvellous footage of since-vanished Melbourne vistas.

Detailed Description Reel 6:

Begins with flag raising outside Melbourne Town Hall. 00:01:05:00 aerial shots of Swanston Street, Flinders Street Station & St. Kilda Road. 00:01:19:00 a shot back across river to Flinders Street showing frontage of St. Paul’s Cathedral and the Ball and Welch store. 00:02:01:00 aerial shot of Government House. 00:02:04:00 arrival at Government House, with crowd scenes including Girl Guides and Brownies in uniforms. 00:03:12:00 reviewing troops including mounted police. 00:04:09:00 Queen mounts steps and enters Government House. 00:04:19 Royal Standard flying over Government House (only flown when monarch in residence). 00:04:22:00 night scenes of Melbourne CBD with illuminated decorations. 00:05:50:00 fireworks shots (to end).

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 5 focuses on the day the Queen and Duke arrived in Melbourne, and consists mainly of short sections of footage, much of which is also seen in other Reels of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 5:

Opens with Queen and Duke leaving Parliament House. Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod flank the couple on the street as they re-enter their car. 00:00:35:00 car moves off to waves from crowd on steps of Parliament building. 00:00:46:00 scenes of the crowd dispersing. 00:01:02:00 4 gun artillery salute fired in Domain. 00:02:07:00 footage returns to State Parliament, and the Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod preceding the Queen and Duke down the steps of the building. 00:02:22:00 a shot upwards to the Royal Standard flying over Parliament House also captures the intricate design under the eaves of the building. 00:02:36:00 scenes of the large crowd outside Parliament House dispersing after the Queen and Duke have left. 00:03:15:00 clear shot of St Paul’s Cathedral spire. 00:03:21:00 workman on ladder in middle of city street tries to adjust one of the large street banners decorating the scene, followed by scenes of city streets and decorations (much of this section is out of focus). 00:04:34 a colleague appears to be giving directions to the camera operator shooting the scene, as the royal motorcade moves down Swanston Street. 00:05:05:00 aerial shot of Princes Bridge with the decorated dome of Flinders Street railway Station in the foreground, with Government House and Prince Henry’s Hospital (demolished in 1994). 00:05:20:00 aerial shot of thick crowd on Princes Bridge; green trams can be seen at the old Batman Avenue tram stop where part of Federation Square now stands. 00:05:28:00 distance shot of Government House. 00:05:34:00 very blurred aerial footage of Swanston Street. 00:06:07:00 aerial shot of Princes Bridge looking back towards Flinders Street, showing the Railway Station, St Paul’s Cathedral and shop frontages along Flinders Street. 00:06:24:00 aerial shots of motorcade approaching Government House. 00:06:47:00 crowds of (mainly children) shot from moving car. 00:07:12:00 aerial shot of Queen reviewing mounted police. 00:07:27:00 close-up of Royal Standard. 00:07:33:00 Girl Guides and Brownies cheering and waving (this footage is quite jerky and flickering). 00:08:33:00 Queen and Duke exiting car at Government House. 00:09:18:00 Queen reviewing police or troops. 00:09:48:00 abrupt change to footage of train speeding along tracks. At 00:10:02:00 to 00:10:47:00 we have what appears to be the start of a staged sequence - a hot and weary sightseer carrying a backpack and sporting Union Jack flags approaches the gates of Government House and is directed away by a soldier on duty. He then sits down by a crowd barrier, removes his shoes and drinks from a flask. From 00:10:59:00 to end of Reel there are a number of short scenes of troops, the Queens and Duke and various others outside Government House.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was our first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This collection of silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 4 shows the arrival and reception of the royal couple at Essendon Airport and their first progress through Melbourne.

Detailed Description Reel 4:

Opens with footage of arrival and reception at Melbourne Airport (Essendon). Official reception party greets the couple at exit from plane. 00:00:15:00 Party and crowd stand at attention for National Anthem. 00:00:32:00 Military salutes and review of troops. 00:01:10:00 Queen greets airplane crew, then full reception party. 00:02:35:00 Motorcade begins leaving Airport. 00:03:41:00 exterior shot of Essendon Town Hall with decorations and crowd followed by motorcade moving through streets. 00:04:01:0 - 00:04:41:00 reception at Essendon Town Hall entrance. 00:04:42:00 motorcade drives on, with shots of cheering crowds lining streets, shot from moving car. 00:05:35:00 arrival at Victorian State Parliament and shots of cheering crowds. 00:06:33:00 Queen and Duke pause halfway up Parliament House steps, flanked by Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod, who then precede them into the Parliament building. The camera then pans up the building to show the royal coat-of-arms and Royal Standard adorning the top. 00:06:59:00 artillery salute fired in Domain. 00:07:18:00 Queen and Duke exit building. 00:07:40:00 on return to their car the Queen and Duke are again flanked by the Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod. 00:08:00:00 car moves off, and is then filmed driving through Melbourne CBD through streets lined with cheering and flag-waving crowds. 00:08:35:00 exterior shot of Melbourne Town Hall.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Reel 3 focuses on the day the Queen and Duke arrived in Melbourne, and consists mainly of short sections of footage, much of which is also seen in other Reels of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 3:

Opens with aerial view of motorcade at top of Bourke Street, Melbourne, (probably leaving Parliament House). At 00:00:11:00 footage switches to Essendon Airport, with officials and police arriving in car and on motorbikes: 00:00:31:00 Crowds are seen waiting for the Queen’s arrival. 00:00:41:00 Arrival of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks. 00:00:50:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:01:07:00 footage of crowds along streets from moving car. 00:01:12:00 Queen and Duke walking across tarmac at Essendon Airport. 00:01:20:00 photographers filming the crowds from a moving car. 00:01:24:00 back at Essendon Airport, assembled sailors. 00:01:30:00 close-ups of various officials at, and leaving, Airport. 00:02:25:00 Queen and Duke exiting aeroplane. 00:02:34:00 Queen and Duke reviewing assembled sailors. 00:02:55:00 Queen and Duke in car beginning to leave airport, crowds running to view car. 00:03:07:00 close-up of luggage. 00:03:10:00 staff exiting plane. 00:03:35:00 drive past Essendon Town Hall with crowds on balcony of Town Hall and lining streets. 00:04:00:00 Crowds in street. 00:04:11:00 Queen and Duke on dais, Mayor making a speech. 00:05:08:00 street scene (probably in Essendon), with large crowd in process of dispersing. 00:05:18:00 cars leaving Essendon Town Hall. 00:05:35:00 crowd on steps of State Parliament shot from moving car. 00:05:51:00 crowds behind barriers lining CBD streets. 00:06:12:00 close-up of Henry Bolte, then leader of the Opposition Victorian Liberal Party, on street outside Parliament House. 00:06:27:00 close-up of Queen and Duke getting into car. 00:06:54:00 close-up of people in crowd with spires of St Patrick’s Cathedral in background. 00:07:37:00 State Parliament building, assembled police. 00:07:41:00 people watching from the top of the Imperial Hotel (still extant on the corner Bourke and Spring Streets, Melbourne), and a “Molina’s” sign can be seen (indicating Melbourne’s famous Molina’s Cafe). 00:07:49:00 close-up of workman affixing red carpet to steps of State Parliament; results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 2 of the collection dwells on the decorations that celebrated the visit, in the streets and on the buildings of Melbourne’s CBD, then shows the officials and staff responsible for the planning and conduct of the tour at work inside the (now demolished) Geological Museum. We are shown the Victorian police reinforcements arranged for the visit being addressed by their commanders, before the scene shifts to Essendon Airport and the preparations for touchdown of the ‘royal’ plane.

Detailed Description Reel 2:

Opens with Title “Melbourne: City decorations”, followed by footage of Melbourne CBD streets and buildings sporting decorations for the visit (Flinders Street Railway Station from Elizabeth Street, Myer Emporium, Swanston Street, the Leviathan Building, trams and cars). 00:00:54:00 shot of old Princes Bridge Railway Station (partially obscured). 00:01:15:00 The Commercial Bank of Australia. 00:01:25:00 decorated Melbourne Town Hall. 00:01:31:0 Foy and Gibson building. 00:01:35:00 emu and kangaroo diorama. 00:01:59:0 Title “Royal Visit Offices: Geological Museum” followed by footage of the exterior of the (now demolished) building in Macarthur Street, and scenes of the staff at work inside. 00:03:32:00 Title “Police Re-Inforcements: The Chief Commissioner and the Chief Secretary address 750 men prior to the visit.” followed by footage of uniformed police being addressed by the commanders. 00:04:25:00 Title “Official Landing & Reception: Melbourne Airport - Overseas Terminal Wednesday, 24th. February, 1954” followed by footage of preparations for the arrival, men in top-hats, men in uniform and waiting crowd. 00:05:12:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:05:36:00 arrival and close-up of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks as he exits car. 00:05:44:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band and sailors marching. 00:06:04:00 plane taxis onto tarmac, close-up of royal coat of arms on plane, which is flying the Royal Standard. Camera pans across “Australian National Airways Pty Ltd - Royal Mail” written on side of plane. Exit stairs are wheeled up to plane, and the Queen and Duke step out.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 1 of this extraordinary collection corresponds to the first 11 minutes of the official State Film Centre release (see ACMI Collection Title [315392]) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”. It shows some of the preparations for the visit, the arrival by plane of the royal couple at Essendon Airport and their first progress through Melbourne to State Parliament and Government House. We see the Queen opening State Parliament, visiting the MCG to meet with Australian armed servicemen and women, attending a special race meeting at Flemington Racecourse and a Davis Cup game at Kooyong Tennis Centre. The Queen and Duke also go to St Paul’s Cathedral, and the reel closes with the official dedication of the forecourt and eternal flame at Melbourne’s Shrine of Remembrance.

Detailed Description Reel 1:

Opens with Titles:
1) “The State Film Centre Presents”
2) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”
3) “Filmed with the co-operation of State Government Departments, Cine Service Pty. Ltd., and The Films Advisory Bureau”
00:00:42:00. Followed by shot of exterior of Geological Museum (this building at 55 McArthur St East Melbourne, used as the Government offices for the Royal Visit; was demolished 1964), and footage of the State Director and staff at work.
00:00:59:00 footage of street scenes and close-ups of decorated buildings in Melbourne CBD (moving diorama of kangaroo and emu above The Myer Emporium 00:01:09:0 to 00:01:16:0).
00:01:27 Essendon Airport awaiting the arrival of the royal visitors.
00:01:38:00 close up of then Governor Dallas Brooks; John Cain Snr (then Premier) also present.
00:01:40:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band.
00:01:50:00 plane lands.
00:02:03:00 Queen & Duke exit plane and are greeted by Governor and Premier on tarmac.
00:02:23:00 Queen reviews guard of honour provided by troops from Royal Australian Navy.
00:02:39:00 Queen & Duke are introduced to a succession of “leading citizens”.
00:03:02:00 car begins departure from airport, and drives through crowd-lined streets.
00:03:24:00 car arrives at Parliament House, Melbourne, where a crowd fills the front steps.
00:03:33:00 Queen and Duke stand halfway up steps and are flanked by Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod (probably being held by Serjeant-at-Arms and Usher of the Black Rod).
00:03:40:00 Royal Salute - 4 gun artillery salute fired in Domain.
00:03:42:00 Queen and Duke descend steps of Parliament House, Melbourne.
00:03:46:00 drives through crowd-lined streets of Melbourne CBD, with Queen & Duke waving and smiling at crowds.
00:03:52:00 aerial shot of Collins Street at Spring Street end.
00:04:24:00 aerial shot of corner of Swanston and Flinders Streets (site of future Gas and Fuel buildings and Federation Square).
00:04:27:00 an aerial shot looking back to CBD from St Kilda Rd; Flinders St Station and St Paul’s Cathedral can be identified.
00:04:31:00 aerial distance shot of Government House, Melbourne.
00:04:42:00 car arrives at Government House.
00:05:04:00 shot of Royal Standard flying over Government House (only flown when monarch in residence).
00:05:08 night scenes of Melbourne CBD decorations.
00:05:28:00 night scenes of fireworks.
00:05:36:00 Queen & Duke taking places at opening of Victorian Parliament; footage inside Legislative Council chamber, Queen in state dress and Order of Garter (Duke in uniform).
00:07:42:00 the M.C.G, and an assembly of ex-servicemen and women.
00:08:02:00 shot of airplane in mid-air. 00:08:08:00 children waving flags in crowd.
00:08:13:00 close-up of Queen making speech (into microphone).
00:08:18:00 close-up of technicians broadcasting the speech.
00:08:24:00 Flemington Racecourse, aerial shot of crowd and betting gates.
00:08:36:00 Queen & Dukes’ car arrives, driving down middle of course.
00:08:52:00 horses in saddling paddock. 00:09:01:00 horses racing.
00:09:17:00 Queen presents cup to winning owner & talks to winning jockey.
00:09:25:00 Queen takes her seat in the stands at Kooyong Tennis Centre.
00:09:32:00 tennis being played.
00:09:44:00 shot of film camera operators (possibly filming newsreel footage?).
00:09:46:00 a presentation is made to Queen on the court.
00:09:51:00 shot of exterior of St Paul’s Cathedral (Melbourne), Queen & Duke walk down steps with Archbishop of Melbourne (Joseph Booth).
00:10:02:00 aerial shots of car driving through Melbourne streets.
00:10:05:00 aerial view of Shrine of Remembrance.
00:10:09:00 close-up of Queen making speech at microphone.
00:10:29:00 close-up of Duke listening to speech.
00:10:36:00 aerial shots of listening crowd.
00:11:24:00 Queen pushes some mechanism near microphone, and the Shrine’s eternal flame is seen smoking (as the Queen has just lighted it.)

description_for_label:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 1 of this extraordinary collection corresponds to the first 11 minutes of the official State Film Centre release (see ACMI Collection Title [315392]) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”. It shows some of the preparations for the visit, the arrival by plane of the royal couple at Essendon Airport and their first progress through Melbourne to State Parliament and Government House. We see the Queen opening State Parliament, visiting the MCG to meet with Australian armed servicemen and women, attending a special race meeting at Flemington Racecourse and a Davis Cup game at Kooyong Tennis Centre. The Queen and Duke also go to St Paul’s Cathedral, and the reel closes with the official dedication of the forecourt and eternal flame at Melbourne’s Shrine of Remembrance.

Detailed Description Reel 1:

Opens with Titles:
1) “The State Film Centre Presents”
2) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”
3) “Filmed with the co-operation of State Government Departments, Cine Service Pty. Ltd., and The Films Advisory Bureau”
